   Assessment and Plan
 DEEP VENOUS THROMBOSIS (DVT), LOWER EXTREMITY
 FEVER, UNKNOWN ORIGIN (FUO, HYPERTHERMIA, PYREXIA)
 ELECTROLYTE & FLUID DISORDER, OTHER
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 11**])
 ALTERED MENTAL STATUS (NOT DELIRIUM)
 C. DIFFICILE INFECTION (C DIFF, CDIFF COLITIS, CLOSTRIDIUM DIFFICILE)
 PULMONARY EMBOLISM (PE), ACUTE
   67-year-old man w/ EtOH abuse, recent GIB, h/o DVTs, p/w multifocal
   PEs, now septic.
   # Sepsis
 Resolving, now normotensive. Pt spiking fevers, tachycardic,
   and hypotensive several days ago but without elevation in WBC. Has
   bottles blood Cx growing CoNS, sputum growing multiple GNRs, and stool
   C.diff positive. Did have infiltrate on CXR concerning for VAP.
   Currently on Zosyn, and Vanc PO, Flagyl. 3 sputum cx all growing GNRs.
   Still spiking fevers, new cultures growing Coag (+) Staph.
   - cont Zosyn (Day 6), for GNR
   - cont Vanc IV (Day 3) for GPCs
   - cont Flagyl (Day 7), PO Vanc (Day 5) for C.diff
   - f/u all culture data, obtain specation of GNR/GPCs
   - draw cultures through a-line and CVL lines
   - gentle diuresis to keep even
   # Unresponsive: likely related to Versed in the setting of EtOh abuse;
   however did get lyisi is at risk for intracranial hemorrhage. Head CT
   neg for bleed and he is moving all 4 extremities, so suspect this is
   sedation related. This morning, he is more responsive, following
   commands, but still not opening eyes. Now extubated with significantly
   improving mental status.
   - hold any mind-altering medications
   # Hypoxic Resp Failure: Extubated with improving hypoxia.
   - monitor secretions
   # VAP: + sputum, fevers and new infiltrate. Sputum growing GNR/GPCs
   - cont Zosyn/Vanc for 8 day course unless grows pseudomonas
   # PEs - On admission pt w/ borderline BPs and considered not a surgical
   candidate. Progressively developed worsening tachycardia and hypoxia.
   Formal TTE and Cardiology consult --> TPA for lysis on [**5-17**] with
   improvement of HR and SaO2. Repeat TTE yesterday shows continued
   depressed RV function; however, right ventricular abnl is now better
   characterized as limpoma rather than clot. No evidence of bleeding.
   Also s/p IVC filter placement.
   - appreciate cardiology involvement, s/p lysis by TPA
   - cont lovenox to help minimize fluid intake, holding off on coumadin
   pending GI evaluation
   # Edema - Pt w/ increased edema as he has gotten several IVF boluses
   for his Hypotension. Lasix gtt w/ good effect on UOP, although pt still
   getting quite a bit of fluid in.
   - check for obligate Ins, consider changing some meds to PO rather than
   IV
   - cont lasix gtt to keep negative
   # Hypotension - Developed post-lysis w/ TPA. Responsive to IVF.
   Initially thought to be [**2-15**] micro-emboli and expected to improve, but
   now more likely related to underlying infection and fevers. Transiently
   required pressors, but now off.
   - cont to monitor BP closely
   - continue home Florinef
   # Anemia - Likely dilutional considering pt received 4L PRBCs, but in
   setting of lysis and vague h/o GIB. HCT down 32->29. No melena.
   - Guaiac stools
   - recheck HCt
   # Alcohol withdrawal - Significant EtOH history. Should now be out of
   window for withdrawal.
   - daily thiamine / MVI / folate
   - SW consult
   # Recent GIB - Unclear history, ? significant.
   - PPI IV BID
   - GI consulted, no endoscopy now, but will scope prior to discharge
   # Low phos: resolved
   - replete
   - recheck in pm
   - nutrition consult
   # Renal insufficieny - Improved.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Fibersource HN (Full) - [**2162-5-23**] 06:09 PM 70 mL/hour
   Glycemic Control:  Regular insulin sliding scale

   67-year-old man w/ EtOH abuse, recent GIB, h/o DVTs, p/w multifocal
   PEs, now septic.
   # Sepsis
 Resolving, now normotensive. Pt spiking fevers, tachycardic,
   and hypotensive several days ago but without elevation in WBC. Has
   bottles blood Cx growing CoNS, sputum growing multiple GNRs, and stool
   C.diff positive. Did have infiltrate on CXR concerning for VAP.
   Currently on Zosyn, and Vanc PO, Flagyl. 3 sputum cx all growing GNRs.
   Still spiking fevers, new cultures growing Coag (+) Staph.
   - cont Zosyn (Day 6), for GNR
   - cont Vanc IV (Day 3) for GPCs
   - cont Flagyl (Day 7), PO Vanc (Day 5) for C.diff
   - f/u all culture data, obtain specation of GNR/GPCs
   - draw cultures through a-line and CVL lines
   - gentle diuresis to keep even
   # Unresponsive: likely related to Versed in the setting of EtOh abuse;
   however did get lyisi is at risk for intracranial hemorrhage. Head CT
   neg for bleed and he is moving all 4 extremities, so suspect this is
   sedation related. This morning, he is more responsive, following
   commands, but still not opening eyes. Now extubated with significantly
   improving mental status.
   - hold any mind-altering medications
   # Hypoxic Resp Failure: Extubated with improving hypoxia.
   - monitor secretions
   # VAP: + sputum, fevers and new infiltrate. Sputum growing GNR/GPCs
   - cont Zosyn/Vanc for 8 day course unless grows pseudomonas
   # PEs - On admission pt w/ borderline BPs and considered not a surgical
   candidate. Progressively developed worsening tachycardia and hypoxia.
   Formal TTE and Cardiology consult --> TPA for lysis on [**5-17**] with
   improvement of HR and SaO2. Repeat TTE yesterday shows continued
   depressed RV function; however, right ventricular abnl is now better
   characterized as limpoma rather than clot. No evidence of bleeding.
   Also s/p IVC filter placement.
   - appreciate cardiology involvement, s/p lysis by TPA
   - cont lovenox to help minimize fluid intake, holding off on coumadin
   pending GI evaluation
   # Edema - Pt w/ increased edema as he has gotten several IVF boluses
   for his Hypotension. Lasix gtt w/ good effect on UOP, although pt still
   getting quite a bit of fluid in.
   - check for obligate Ins, consider changing some meds to PO rather than
   IV
   - cont lasix gtt to keep negative
   # Hypotension - Developed post-lysis w/ TPA. Responsive to IVF.
   Initially thought to be [**2-15**] micro-emboli and expected to improve, but
   now more likely related to underlying infection and fevers. Transiently
   required pressors, but now off.
   - cont to monitor BP closely
   - continue home Florinef
   # Anemia - Likely dilutional considering pt received 4L PRBCs, but in
   setting of lysis and vague h/o GIB. HCT down 32->29. No melena.
   - Guaiac stools
   - recheck HCt
   # Alcohol withdrawal - Significant EtOH history. Should now be out of
   window for withdrawal.
   - daily thiamine / MVI / folate
   - SW consult
   # Recent GIB - Unclear history, ? significant.
   - PPI IV BID
   - GI consulted, no endoscopy now, but will scope prior to discharge
   # Low phos: resolved
   - replete
   - recheck in pm
   - nutrition consult
   # Renal insufficieny - Improved.

Based on the patient's progress note, I summarize the following key points:

1. The patient is a 67-year-old man with a history of EtOH abuse, recent gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB), and a history of deep venous thrombosis (DVT).
2. The patient has been intubated and mechanically ventilated since admission due to respiratory failure and acute hypoxic respiratory failure.
3. The patient has been experiencing fever, tachycardia, and hypotension, which has resolved with treatment.
4. The patient has been diagnosed with sepsis, with cultures growing Coag (+) Staph, GNRs, and C. difficile.
5. The patient has been treated with Zosyn, Vanc, and Flagyl, and has had multiple sputum cultures growing GNRs.
6. The patient has been extubated and is now on a low-flow oxygen therapy.
7. The patient has been diagnosed with DVT, pulmonary embolism (PE), and has undergone lysis with tissue plasminogen activator (TPA).
8. The patient has been treated with lovenox to help minimize fluid intake and has had an IVC filter placed.
9. The patient has been experiencing edema due to IVF boluses, and has been treated with lasix gtt to keep negative.
10. The patient has been experiencing hypotension, which has resolved with treatment.
11. The patient has been diagnosed with anemia, likely due to dilutional anemia, and has been treated with thiamine, MVI, and folate.
12. The patient has been experiencing low phosphorus levels, which have resolved with treatment.
13. The patient has been diagnosed with renal insufficiency, which has improved with treatment.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Pneumonia: The patient has been experiencing fever, tachycardia, and hypoxia, which may indicate pneumonia.
2. Sepsis: The patient has been diagnosed with sepsis, which can lead to multi-organ dysfunction and death.
3. DVT: The patient has a history of DVT and has been diagnosed with DVT, which can lead to pulmonary embolism and death.
4. PE: The patient has been diagnosed with PE, which can lead to respiratory failure and death.
5. C. difficile infection: The patient has been diagnosed with C. difficile infection, which can lead to colitis and death.
6. Renal insufficiency: The patient has been diagnosed with renal insufficiency, which can lead to acute kidney injury and death.
7. Anemia: The patient has been diagnosed with anemia, which can lead to fatigue, shortness of breath, and decreased cognitive function.
8. Hypotension: The patient has been experiencing hypotension, which can lead to shock and death.
9. Fluid overload: The patient has been experiencing edema and fluid overload, which can lead to respiratory failure and death.

It is essential to continue monitoring the patient's condition and treating any potential complications promptly to prevent further deterioration and improve the patient's outcome.

   67-year-old man w/ EtOH abuse, recent GIB, h/o DVTs, p/w multifocal
   PEs, now septic.
   # Sepsis
 Resolving, now normotensive. Pt spiking fevers, tachycardic,
   and hypotensive several days ago but without elevation in WBC. Has
   bottles blood Cx growing CoNS, sputum growing multiple GNRs, and stool
   C.diff positive. Did have infiltrate on CXR concerning for VAP.
   Currently on Zosyn, and Vanc PO, Flagyl. 3 sputum cx all growing GNRs.
   Still spiking fevers, new cultures growing Coag (+) Staph.
   - cont Zosyn (Day 6), for GNR
   - cont Vanc IV (Day 3) for GPCs
   - cont Flagyl (Day 7), PO Vanc (Day 5) for C.diff
   - f/u all culture data, obtain specation of GNR/GPCs
   - draw cultures through a-line and CVL lines
   - gentle diuresis to keep even
   # Unresponsive: likely related to Versed in the setting of EtOh abuse;
   however did get lyisi is at risk for intracranial hemorrhage. Head CT
   neg for bleed and he is moving all 4 extremities, so suspect this is
   sedation related. This morning, he is more responsive, following
   commands, but still not opening eyes. Now extubated with significantly
   improving mental status.
   - hold any mind-altering medications
   # Hypoxic Resp Failure: Extubated with improving hypoxia.
   - monitor secretions
   # VAP: + sputum, fevers and new infiltrate. Sputum growing GNR/GPCs
   - cont Zosyn/Vanc for 8 day course unless grows pseudomonas
   # PEs - On admission pt w/ borderline BPs and considered not a surgical
   candidate. Progressively developed worsening tachycardia and hypoxia.
   Formal TTE and Cardiology consult --> TPA for lysis on [**5-17**] with
   improvement of HR and SaO2. Repeat TTE yesterday shows continued
   depressed RV function; however, right ventricular abnl is now better
   characterized as limpoma rather than clot. No evidence of bleeding.
   Also s/p IVC filter placement.
   - appreciate cardiology involvement, s/p lysis by TPA
   - cont lovenox to help minimize fluid intake, holding off on coumadin
   pending GI evaluation
   # Edema - Pt w/ increased edema as he has gotten several IVF boluses
   for his Hypotension. Lasix gtt w/ good effect on UOP, although pt still
   getting quite a bit of fluid in.
   - check for obligate Ins, consider changing some meds to PO rather than
   IV
   - cont lasix gtt to keep negative
   # Hypotension - Developed post-lysis w/ TPA. Responsive to IVF.
   Initially thought to be [**2-15**] micro-emboli and expected to improve, but
   now more likely related to underlying infection and fevers. Transiently
   required pressors, but now off.
   - cont to monitor BP closely
   - continue home Florinef
   # Anemia - Likely dilutional considering pt received 4L PRBCs, but in
   setting of lysis and vague h/o GIB. HCT down 32->29. No melena.
   - Guaiac stools
   - recheck HCt
   # Alcohol withdrawal - Significant EtOH history. Should now be out of
   window for withdrawal.
   - daily thiamine / MVI / folate
   - SW consult
   # Recent GIB - Unclear history, ? significant.
   - PPI IV BID
   - GI consulted, no endoscopy now, but will scope prior to discharge
   # Low phos: resolved
   - replete
   - recheck in pm
   - nutrition consult
   # Renal insufficieny - Improved.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 67-year-old man with a history of ethanol abuse, recent gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB), and deep vein thrombosis (DVT). He was admitted with sepsis, multifocal pulmonary embolisms (PEs), and respiratory failure. The patient has been treated with various antibiotics, including Zosyn, Vanc, and Flagyl, and has been extubated.

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is extubated and improving in terms of oxygenation, with a SpO2 of 96%.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has had a recent episode of hypotension, which has resolved with IV fluids. He has also had a pulmonary embolism (PE) and has been treated with thrombolytic therapy (TPA) and an inferior vena cava (IVC) filter.
* Neurological: The patient has had altered mental status, which has improved with sedation hold and has been extubated.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has had gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB) and is receiving proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy.
* Renal: The patient has had acute kidney injury (AKI) and is receiving dialysis.
* Hematology: The patient has had anemia and is receiving transfusions.
* Infectious disease: The patient has had sepsis and has been treated with antibiotics. He has also had a positive stool culture for Clostridioides difficile (C. diff).

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient may experience respiratory failure due to his underlying lung disease and the presence of a pulmonary embolism.
* Sepsis: The patient may experience sepsis due to his underlying infection and the presence of multiple bacteria in his blood and stool cultures.
* Pneumonia: The patient may develop pneumonia due to the presence of bacteria in his respiratory tract.
* Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient may develop DVT due to his underlying hypercoagulable state and the presence of a pulmonary embolism.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB): The patient may experience GIB due to his underlying gastrointestinal disease and the presence of bacteria in his stool cultures.
* Renal insufficiency: The patient may experience renal insufficiency due to his underlying kidney disease and the presence of antibiotics.
* Anemia: The patient may experience anemia due to his underlying blood loss and the presence of antibiotics.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Antibiotics: The patient will continue to receive antibiotics to treat his underlying infection.
* Respiratory support: The patient will receive respiratory support, including oxygen therapy and mechanical ventilation if necessary.
* Cardiovascular support: The patient will receive cardiovascular support, including IV fluids and pressors if necessary.
* Gastrointestinal support: The patient will receive gastrointestinal support, including proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy and antibiotics if necessary.
* Renal support: The patient will receive renal support, including dialysis if necessary.
* Hematological support: The patient will receive hematological support, including transfusions if necessary.

The patient's discharge plan includes:

* Home oxygen therapy: The patient will require home oxygen therapy to support his respiratory function.
* Antibiotics: The patient will require antibiotics to treat his underlying infection.
* Proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy: The patient will require PPI therapy to treat his underlying gastrointestinal disease.
* Dialysis: The patient will require dialysis if necessary to support his renal function.
* Follow-up: The patient will require follow-up appointments with his primary care physician and specialists to monitor his progress and adjust his treatment plan as necessary.

The patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of DVTs, GIB, and multifocal PEs. He was recently treated with thrombolysis and has an IVC filter in place. The patient has ongoing medical issues, including:

* VAP with sputum positive for GNR
* C. difficile infection
* Volume overload
* Hypotension
* Renal insufficiency
* FEN-replete electrolytes
* Phosphate imbalance
* Recent GIB with risk of rebleeding
* Hypocalcemia
* Hypomagnesemia
* Hyperphosphatemia

The patient has undergone various treatments, including:

* TPA for submassive pulmonary emboli
* Lovenox for anticoagulation
* Lasix for diuresis
* Piperacillin-tazobactam for antibiotics
* Vancomycin for antibiotics
* Pantoprazole for stress ulcer prophylaxis
* Furosemide for diuresis

Potential medical complications:

1. Rebleeding from recent GIB: The patient will require a scope to evaluate the risk of rebleeding and may need anticoagulation once acute issues are resolved.
2. VAP and C. difficile infection: The patient's VAP and C. difficile infection require ongoing treatment with antibiotics and close monitoring.
3. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may require further treatment with vasopressors such as levophed.
4. Renal insufficiency: The patient's renal insufficiency may require further treatment with diuretics and close monitoring of electrolyte levels.
5. FEN-replete electrolytes: The patient's electrolyte imbalance may require further treatment with electrolyte replacement and close monitoring.
6. Phosphate imbalance: The patient's phosphate imbalance may require further treatment with phosphate replacement and close monitoring.
7. Hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia: The patient's hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia may require further treatment with calcium and magnesium replacement and close monitoring.
8. Hyperphosphatemia: The patient's hyperphosphatemia may require further treatment with phosphate binders and close monitoring.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent these potential complications and ensure the patient's overall well-being.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and recent gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB). He has multifocal pulmonary emboli (PE) and was treated with thrombolytic therapy on [**5-17**]. The patient is currently intubated and sedated, with pinpoint pupils and jugular venous distension (JVD) elevated.

The patient has several ongoing medical issues, including:

1. Pulmonary Emboli: The patient has multifocal PE, which is a potential life-threatening condition. The patient is being treated with lovenox and will continue to be monitored closely for any signs of worsening pulmonary emboli.
2. Fever/VAP/C. Diff: The patient has a fever, which is likely related to a ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and Clostridioides difficile (C. diff) infection. The patient will continue to receive antibiotics until the final culture results are available.
3. Hypotension: The patient has had episodes of hypotension, which have been resolved with the administration of fluorinef. The patient will continue to receive this medication as needed.
4. Renal Insufficiency: The patient has had evidence of renal insufficiency, which has improved with the administration of diuretics.
5. FEN-Replete: The patient has been replete with electrolytes and has had his phosphorus levels corrected.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count (WBC): 13.6
* Hematocrit (Hct): 28.4
* Platelet count (Plt): 351
* Creatinine (Cr): 1.0
* Total CO2 (TCO2): 33
* Glucose: 127
* Other laboratory results are within normal limits.

The patient's imaging studies show:

* Chest X-ray: Improved RLL infiltrate
* CT brain: No focal abnormalities

The patient's plan includes:

1. Continue lovenox and monitor for signs of worsening pulmonary emboli.
2. Continue antibiotics until final culture results are available.
3. Continue diuretics to manage fluid overload.
4. Continue electrolyte replacement and phosphorus correction.
5. Monitor for signs of alcohol withdrawal and provide daily thiamine and MVI.
6. Consider scope to evaluate risk for rebleeding in the future.
7. Continue PPI and follow-up Hcts.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Worsening pulmonary emboli
* C. diff infection
* VAP
* Renal insufficiency
* Electrolyte imbalance
* Phosphorus deficiency
* Hypotension
* Cerebral bleeding (if no improvement in mental status)

The patient's overall condition is stable, but he requires close monitoring and ongoing management of his medical issues to prevent potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with a complex medical condition. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.4°C, heart rate of 117 bpm, and blood pressure of 119/66 mmHg. The patient is receiving invasive ventilation, which was stopped at 09:54 AM, and is on various medications, including antibiotics, anticoagulants, and diuretics.

The patient has a deep venous thrombosis (DVT) in the lower extremity, fever of unknown origin, electrolyte and fluid disorder, respiratory failure, altered mental status, Clostridium difficile infection, and acute pulmonary embolism.

Physical examination reveals an unassessed peripheral vascular system, skin, and neurologic system. Laboratory results show anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated white blood cell count. The patient's kidney function is impaired, with elevated creatinine and blood urea nitrogen levels.

Potential medical complications:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's respiratory failure and altered mental status increase the risk of developing pneumonia.
2. Sepsis: The patient's fever of unknown origin and Clostridium difficile infection may lead to sepsis, which can cause organ dysfunction and death.
3. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) progression: The patient's DVT may progress and cause pulmonary embolism, which can be life-threatening.
4. Kidney injury: The patient's impaired kidney function may worsen, leading to acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
5. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's electrolyte disorder may worsen, leading to cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and other complications.
6. C. difficile colitis: The patient's C. difficile infection may worsen, leading to severe colitis, toxic megacolon, and death.
7. Pulmonary embolism: The patient's acute pulmonary embolism may worsen, leading to respiratory failure, cardiac arrest, and death.
8. Septic shock: The patient's sepsis may progress to septic shock, which can cause multi-organ failure and death.

Given the patient's complex medical condition, it is essential to monitor their vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical condition closely to prevent and manage potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of DVT, recent gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB), and multifocal pulmonary emboli (PE) who was treated with thrombolysis and an IVC filter. He is currently intubated and receiving invasive ventilation. The patient has a history of alcoholism and is experiencing withdrawal symptoms, which have improved. He is also experiencing fevers, ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), and Clostridioides difficile (C. diff) infection.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pulmonary Embolism: The patient has multifocal PE, which is a significant risk factor for further embolic events. Close monitoring of his condition is necessary to prevent further complications.
2. VAP: The patient has a VAP infection, which can lead to respiratory failure and sepsis. Antibiotic therapy and respiratory support are necessary to manage this condition.
3. C. diff Infection: The patient has a C. diff infection, which can lead to severe diarrhea, colitis, and potentially life-threatening complications. Close monitoring of his stool output and gut function is necessary to prevent further complications.
4. Renal Insufficiency: The patient has renal insufficiency, which can lead to electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, and potentially life-threatening complications. Close monitoring of his renal function and electrolyte levels is necessary to prevent further complications.
5. Hypotension: The patient has experienced hypotension, which can lead to organ dysfunction and potentially life-threatening complications. Close monitoring of his blood pressure and cardiovascular status is necessary to prevent further complications.
6. Respiratory Failure: The patient is intubated and receiving invasive ventilation, which can lead to respiratory failure and potentially life-threatening complications. Close monitoring of his respiratory status and ventilator settings is necessary to prevent further complications.
7. Sepsis: The patient has a history of GIB and is experiencing fevers, which can lead to sepsis. Close monitoring of his temperature and inflammatory markers is necessary to prevent further complications.
8. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient has a history of GIB, which can lead to further bleeding and potentially life-threatening complications. Close monitoring of his gastrointestinal status and stool output is necessary to prevent further complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's condition closely for signs of pulmonary embolism, VAP, C. diff infection, renal insufficiency, hypotension, respiratory failure, sepsis, and gastrointestinal bleeding.
2. Continue antibiotic therapy for VAP and C. diff infection.
3. Continue respiratory support with invasive ventilation and monitor the patient's respiratory status closely.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function and electrolyte levels closely and adjust his fluid management and medication regimen as necessary.
5. Consider further diagnostic testing, such as a scope, to evaluate the patient's risk for rebleeding and to determine the best course of treatment for his gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's blood pressure and cardiovascular status closely and adjust his medication regimen as necessary.
7. Consider further antibiotic therapy for the patient's gastrointestinal bleeding if necessary.
8. Monitor the patient's stool output and gut function closely and adjust his medication regimen as necessary to prevent further complications.

   Assessment and Plan
 PAIN CONTROL (ACUTE PAIN, CHRONIC PAIN)
 DEEP VENOUS THROMBOSIS (DVT), LOWER EXTREMITY
 FEVER, UNKNOWN ORIGIN (FUO, HYPERTHERMIA, PYREXIA)
 ELECTROLYTE & FLUID DISORDER, OTHER
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 11**])
 ALTERED MENTAL STATUS (NOT DELIRIUM)
 C. DIFFICILE INFECTION (C DIFF, CDIFF COLITIS, CLOSTRIDIUM DIFFICILE)
 PULMONARY EMBOLISM (PE), ACUTE
   67-year-old man w/ EtOH abuse, recent GIB, h/o DVTs, p/w multifocal
   PEs, now septic.
   # PEs - On admission pt w/ borderline BPs and considered not a surgical
   candidate. Progressively developed worsening tachycardia and hypoxia.
   Formal TTE and Cardiology consult --> TPA for lysis on [**5-17**] with
   improvement of HR and SaO2. Repeat TTE [**5-18**]  shows continued depressed
   RV function; however, right ventricular abnl is now better
   characterized as limpoma rather than clot. No evidence of bleeding.
   Also s/p IVC filter placement. Blood pressure recently stable.
   - appreciate cardiology involvement, s/p lysis by TPA
   - cont lovenox to help minimize fluid intake, holding off on coumadin
   pending GI evaluation
   # VAP
   Clinically improved without significant fever or sputum in the last
   day. Sputum growing Citrobacter, Aeromonas, and vancomycin
   - Complete 8d course of Zosyn and vancomycin
   # Edema
   Total body overloaded in the setting of IVF resuscitation for his
   hypotension.
   - Continue IV lasix boluses goal -1 to 2L negative
   # Anemia
   Hct trending down, without any evidence of gross bleeding here. Of
   note, he does have a history of GIB and is s/p thrombolysis and on
   LMWH. Macrocytosis likely secondary to liver disease, but consider also
   b12 deficiency.
   - Follow Hct [**Hospital1 7**]
   - Continue PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - Maintain active T+S, transfuse hct>25
   - PIV x2
   - GI to perform EGD and colonoscopy on floor
   - Check iron panel, folate, b12
   # C diff colitis
   Clinically improved, has been treated with both PO vancomycin and
   metronidazole.
   - Complete 10d course of PO vancomycin following completion of Zosyn
   for HAP
   - Discontinue PO metronidazole
   # Alcohol withdrawal - Significant EtOH history. Should now be out of
   window for withdrawal.
   - daily thiamine / MVI / folate
   - SW consult
   # Renal insufficieny - Improved.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Fibersource HN (Full) - [**2162-5-24**] 10:35 PM 70 mL/hour
   Glycemic Control:  Comments: humalog sliding scale
   Lines:
   Multi Lumen - [**2162-5-19**] 10:35 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: (Systemic anticoagulation: LMWH Heparin)
   Stress ulcer: PPI
   VAP:  not intubated
   Communication: Patient discussed on interdisciplinary rounds , ICU
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition:Transfer to floor

Summary:

The patient is a 67-year-old man with a history of ethanol abuse, recent gastrointestinal bleeding, and multiple deep vein thromboses (DVTs). He was admitted with hypoxia and has been treated with various medications, including antibiotics, anticoagulants, and pain management. His condition has improved, but he still has several ongoing issues, including:

* Citrobacter freundii complex, Aeromonas hydrophila, and Staph aureus coag+ infections, with pending sensitivities
* Respiratory failure, acute, not ARDS
* Altered mental status, not delirium
* C. difficile infection, treated with PO vancomycin and metronidazole
* Pulmonary embolism (PE), acute, treated with TPA for lysis
* Deep venous thrombosis (DVT), lower extremity
* Fever, unknown origin (FUO, hyperthermia, pyrexia)
* Electrolyte and fluid disorder, other
* Anemia, trending down, with possible macrocytosis and b12 deficiency
* Edema, total body overloaded
* Renal insufficiency, improved

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's infections, particularly the Citrobacter freundii complex and Aeromonas hydrophila, may lead to sepsis, which can be life-threatening.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's acute respiratory failure may worsen, requiring more aggressive respiratory support or even mechanical ventilation.
3. Pulmonary embolism: The patient's PE may recur or worsen, leading to further respiratory compromise or even death.
4. Deep vein thrombosis: The patient's DVT may extend or embolize, leading to further complications, such as pulmonary embolism or post-thrombotic syndrome.
5. C. difficile colitis: The patient's C. difficile infection may recur or worsen, leading to further gastrointestinal complications, such as colitis or toxic megacolon.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen, requiring transfusions or other interventions.
7. Electrolyte and fluid disorder: The patient's electrolyte and fluid disorder may lead to further complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, or even cardiac arrest.
8. Renal insufficiency: The patient's renal insufficiency may worsen, leading to further complications, such as acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.

Given the patient's complex medical condition and ongoing issues, close monitoring and management are essential to prevent or mitigate these potential complications.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following medical complications can arise:

1. Sepsis: The patient has a positive culture growing Citrobacter freundii complex, Aeromonas hydrophila, and Staph aureus coag+, which can lead to sepsis.
2. Pneumonia: The patient has been diagnosed with ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and is receiving antibiotics for Citrobacter, Aeromonas, and vancomycin.
3. Hypotension: The patient has been experiencing hypotension, which can be exacerbated by fluid overload and cardiac dysfunction.
4. Cardiac dysfunction: The patient has a history of pulmonary embolism and has been treated with thrombolytic therapy, which can lead to cardiac dysfunction.
5. Anemia: The patient has a decreasing hematocrit, which can be due to chronic blood loss, hemolysis, or bone marrow failure.
6. Edema: The patient has total body overload, which can lead to edema and worsening respiratory function.
7. C. diff colitis: The patient has a history of C. diff colitis and is receiving treatment with PO vancomycin.
8. GI bleeding: The patient has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding and is at risk for further bleeding due to his condition.
9. Liver dysfunction: The patient has macrocytosis, which can be secondary to liver disease, and may be at risk for further liver dysfunction.
10. Thrombosis: The patient has a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE), and is at risk for further thrombotic events.
11. Worsening respiratory function: The patient has a history of respiratory failure and is at risk for further worsening of his respiratory function due to his condition.
12. Neurological complications: The patient has a history of EtOH abuse and may be at risk for neurological complications such as seizures, stroke, or encephalopathy.

The patient's current medications include:

* Antibiotics: Zosyn, vancomycin, and metronidazole
* Diuretics: Furosemide (Lasix) boluses
* Cardiovascular medications: Pantoprazole (Protonix), enoxaparin (Lovenox)
* Anticoagulants: LMWH (lovenox)
* Pain management: None mentioned
* Nutritional support: Fibersource HN (Full)

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 13.6
* Hct: 28.4
* Platelets: 351
* Creatinine: 1.0
* Troponin-T: 0.03
* Lactic acid: 1.1 mmol/L
* Albumin: 1.9 g/dL
* LDH: 333 IU/L
* Calcium: 7.6 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.1 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 2.4 mg/dL

The patient's radiology results show:

* CXR: shows a small retrocardiac atelectasis and minimal obliteration of the right costophrenic sinus, suggesting a small right-sided pleural effusion.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue antibiotics for VAP
* Continue diuretics for edema
* Monitor for signs of sepsis and cardiac dysfunction
* Continue thromboprophylaxis with LMWH
* Monitor for signs of C. diff colitis and GI bleeding
* Perform EGD and colonoscopy on the floor
* Check iron panel, folate, and B12 levels
* Continue PPI and consider switching to oral medication
* Maintain active T+S and transfuse Hct > 25
* Place two PIV lines and consider removing CVL once PIV is in
* SW consult for alcohol withdrawal.

 PULMONARY EMBOLISM (PE), ACUTE
   67-year-old man w/ EtOH abuse, recent GIB, h/o DVTs, p/w multifocal
   PEs, now septic.
   # PEs - On admission pt w/ borderline BPs and considered not a surgical
   candidate. Progressively developed worsening tachycardia and hypoxia.
   Formal TTE and Cardiology consult --> TPA for lysis on [**5-17**] with
   improvement of HR and SaO2. Repeat TTE [**5-18**]  shows continued depressed
   RV function; however, right ventricular abnl is now better
   characterized as limpoma rather than clot. No evidence of bleeding.
   Also s/p IVC filter placement. Blood pressure recently stable.
   - appreciate cardiology involvement, s/p lysis by TPA
   - cont lovenox to help minimize fluid intake, holding off on coumadin
   pending GI evaluation
   # VAP
   Clinically improved without significant fever or sputum in the last
   day. Sputum growing Citrobacter, Aeromonas, and vancomycin
   - Complete 8d course of Zosyn and vancomycin
   # Edema
   Total body overloaded in the setting of IVF resuscitation for his
   hypotension.
   - Continue IV lasix boluses goal -1 to 2L negative
   # Anemia
   Hct trending down, without any evidence of gross bleeding here. Of
   note, he does have a history of GIB and is s/p thrombolysis and on
   LMWH. Macrocytosis likely secondary to liver disease, but consider also
   b12 deficiency.
   - Follow Hct [**Hospital1 7**]
   - Continue PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - Maintain active T+S, transfuse hct>25
   - PIV x2
   - GI to perform EGD and colonoscopy on floor
   - Check iron panel, folate, b12
   # Alcohol withdrawal - Significant EtOH history. Should now be out of
   window for withdrawal.
   - daily thiamine / MVI / folate
   - SW consult
   # Renal insufficieny - Improved.
   ICU Care

   Stress ulcer: PPI

   Communication: Patient discussed on interdisciplinary rounds , ICU
   Code status: Full code

Summary:

The patient is a 67-year-old man with a history of EtOH abuse, recent gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB), and a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). He was admitted to the ICU with hypoxia and was found to have multifocal pulmonary emboli (PEs). He was treated with tissue plasminogen activator (TPA) for lysis and had an improvement in his heart rate and oxygen saturation. He also developed sepsis and was found to have Citrobacter freundii, Aeromonas hydrophila, and Staphylococcus aureus (Coag+) in his sputum. He has been treated with antibiotics and is currently on a ventilator.

The patient's current condition is stable, with his heart rate and oxygen saturation improving. However, he is still at risk for further complications, including respiratory failure, sepsis, and cardiac arrest.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but he is still at risk for further deterioration, especially if his PEs are not fully resolved.
2. Sepsis: The patient has developed sepsis, which can lead to further complications, including organ failure and death.
3. Cardiac arrest: The patient's cardiac status is stable, but he is still at risk for cardiac arrest, especially if his PEs are not fully resolved.
4. Renal insufficiency: The patient's renal function is improving, but he is still at risk for further deterioration, especially if he develops sepsis or cardiac arrest.
5. Neurological complications: The patient's neurological status is stable, but he is still at risk for further complications, including stroke or seizures.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has a history of GIB and is at risk for further gastrointestinal complications, including perforation or bleeding.
7. DVT: The patient has a history of DVT and is at risk for further DVTs, especially if he develops sepsis or cardiac arrest.
8. Pneumonia: The patient's sputum is positive for Citrobacter freundii, Aeromonas hydrophila, and Staphylococcus aureus (Coag+), which can lead to pneumonia.
9. Liver failure: The patient has a history of liver disease and is at risk for further liver failure, especially if he develops sepsis or cardiac arrest.
10. Kidney failure: The patient has a history of kidney disease and is at risk for further kidney failure, especially if he develops sepsis or cardiac arrest.

Summary:

The patient, a 67-year-old man with a history of EtOH abuse, recent gastrointestinal bleeding, and DVTs, is admitted to the ICU with hypoxia. He has been treated with TPA for lysis of pulmonary embolism, and his blood pressure has recently stabilized. The patient has been clinically improved, with no significant fever or sputum production in the last day. Sputum cultures have grown Citrobacter, Aeromonas, and vancomycin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. He has been treated with Lasix boluses for diuresis and has shown improvement in his mental status.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pulmonary Embolism (PE): The patient has a history of multifocal PEs, and his condition is still under close monitoring.
2. Deep Venous Thrombosis (DVT): The patient has a history of DVTs, and his current condition may be a risk factor for DVT recurrence.
3. C. difficile Infection (C. diff): The patient has been treated with both PO vancomycin and metronidazole, and his condition is clinically improved.
4. Renal Insufficiency: The patient's creatinine levels have improved, but he still requires close monitoring of his renal function.
5. Anemia: The patient's Hct is trending down, and he has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding and is s/p thrombolysis and on LMWH.
6. Electrolyte and Fluid Disorder: The patient has a history of IVF resuscitation for his hypotension, and his electrolyte levels are being closely monitored.
7. Fever of Unknown Origin (FUO): The patient has had a fever, but its origin is unknown.
8. Respiratory Failure: The patient has been treated for acute respiratory failure, but his condition is still under close monitoring.
9. Altered Mental Status: The patient's mental status has improved, but he is still at risk for delirium.
10. Pulmonary Edema: The patient has a history of pulmonary embolism and may be at risk for pulmonary edema.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's pulmonary embolism and DVT status.
2. Continue to treat the patient's C. difficile infection with PO vancomycin.
3. Monitor the patient's renal function closely and adjust his fluid and electrolyte management accordingly.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's anemia and consider transfusing him if his Hct drops below 25.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte and fluid disorder and adjust his treatment accordingly.
6. Monitor the patient's fever of unknown origin and consider further evaluation if it persists.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory function and adjust his treatment accordingly.
8. Monitor the patient's mental status and consider further evaluation if he develops delirium.
9. Monitor the patient's pulmonary edema risk and adjust his treatment accordingly.

Summary:

The patient is a 67-year-old man with a history of ethanol abuse, recent gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB), and multiple deep vein thromboses (DVTs). He is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) due to sepsis, respiratory failure, and hypoxic respiratory failure. His laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 13.6, hemoglobin of 8.7 g/dL, and platelet count of 351. His blood cultures are growing Citrobacter freundii complex, Aeromonas hydrophila, and Staphylococcus aureus. He has a small right-sided pleural effusion and minimal obliteration of the right costophrenic sinus on his chest X-ray.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely related to his blood cultures growing multiple organisms, including Citrobacter freundii complex, Aeromonas hydrophila, and Staphylococcus aureus.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely related to his hypoxic respiratory failure and the presence of a small right-sided pleural effusion.
3. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient's hypoxic respiratory failure is likely related to his respiratory failure and the presence of a small right-sided pleural effusion.
4. Pneumonia: The patient's sputum cultures are growing multiple GNRs, which could indicate the presence of pneumonia.
5. C. difficile Infection: The patient's stool culture is positive for C. difficile, which could indicate the presence of C. difficile colitis.
6. Pulmonary Embolism: The patient's previous pulmonary emboli (PEs) and his current hypoxic respiratory failure could indicate the presence of a new PE.
7. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): The patient's history of DVTs and his current hypoxic respiratory failure could indicate the presence of a new DVT.
8. Electrolyte and Fluid Disorder: The patient's electrolyte and fluid disorder could be related to his hypotension, respiratory failure, and hypoxic respiratory failure.
9. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status could be related to his sepsis, hypoxic respiratory failure, and the presence of a small right-sided pleural effusion.
10. Pneumonia with Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia (VAP): The patient's sputum cultures are growing multiple GNRs, which could indicate the presence of VAP.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's assessment and plan include:

1. Continue antibiotics for GNR and GPCs.
2. Monitor for sepsis and adjust therapy as necessary.
3. Continue respiratory support with oxygen therapy.
4. Monitor for respiratory failure and adjust therapy as necessary.
5. Monitor for hypoxic respiratory failure and adjust therapy as necessary.
6. Continue anticoagulation therapy with LMWH to prevent DVT and PE.
7. Monitor for electrolyte and fluid disorder and adjust therapy as necessary.
8. Monitor for altered mental status and adjust therapy as necessary.
9. Continue to monitor for pneumonia and adjust therapy as necessary.
10. Continue to monitor for C. difficile infection and adjust therapy as necessary.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual with multiple comorbidities. The patient's chief complaint is hypoxia, which is likely related to their respiratory failure.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 116 bpm, blood pressure of 121/69 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 23 inspirations per minute. Their oxygen saturation is 96% on nasal cannula.

The patient has a history of sepsis, with multiple organisms cultured from their blood, including Citrobacter freundii complex, Aeromonas hydrophila, and Staphylococcus aureus coag+. They have received multiple antibiotics, including metronidazole, vancomycin, and piperacillin/tazobactam.

The patient has a history of altered mental status, which is improving. They have a deep venous thrombosis in their lower extremity and are at risk for pulmonary embolism.

The patient's laboratory results are notable for an elevated white blood cell count, platelet count, and lactate level. Their kidney function is impaired, with a creatinine level of 1.0 mg/dL.

The patient's plan includes continued treatment for sepsis, respiratory failure, and altered mental status. They will also receive prophylaxis for deep venous thrombosis and stress ulcers.

Potential medical complications that can arise in this patient include:

1. Sepsis-related organ dysfunction: The patient's sepsis can lead to organ dysfunction, including acute kidney injury, acute respiratory distress syndrome, and hepatic dysfunction.
2. Pulmonary embolism: The patient's deep venous thrombosis increases their risk of pulmonary embolism, which can be life-threatening.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure can worsen, leading to increased oxygen requirements and potential need for mechanical ventilation.
4. Electrolyte and fluid disorder: The patient's electrolyte and fluid disorder can worsen, leading to cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and other complications.
5. C. difficile infection: The patient's C. difficile infection can worsen, leading to severe diarrhea, abdominal pain, and potentially life-threatening complications.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust their treatment plan as necessary to prevent these complications and improve their outcomes.

 PULMONARY EMBOLISM (PE), ACUTE
   67-year-old man w/ EtOH abuse, recent GIB, h/o DVTs, p/w multifocal
   PEs, now septic.
   # Sepsis
 Resolving, now normotensive. Pt spiking fevers, tachycardic,
   and hypotensive several days ago but without elevation in WBC. Has
   bottles blood Cx growing CoNS, sputum growing multiple GNRs, and stool
   C.diff positive. Did have infiltrate on CXR concerning for VAP.
   Currently on Zosyn, and Vanc PO, Flagyl. 3 sputum cx all growing GNRs.
   Still spiking fevers, new cultures growing Coag (+) Staph.
   - cont Zosyn (Day 6), for GNR
   - cont Vanc IV (Day 3) for GPCs
   - cont Flagyl (Day 7), PO Vanc (Day 5) for C.diff
   - f/u all culture data, obtain specation of GNR/GPCs
   - draw cultures through a-line and CVL lines
   - gentle diuresis to keep even
   # Unresponsive: likely related to Versed in the setting of EtOh abuse;
   however did get lyisi is at risk for intracranial hemorrhage. Head CT
   neg for bleed and he is moving all 4 extremities, so suspect this is
   sedation related. This morning, he is more responsive, following
   commands, but still not opening eyes. Now extubated with significantly
   improving mental status.
   - hold any mind-altering medications
   # Hypoxic Resp Failure: Extubated with improving hypoxia.
   - monitor secretions
   # VAP: + sputum, fevers and new infiltrate. Sputum growing GNR/GPCs
   - cont Zosyn/Vanc for 8 day course unless grows pseudomonas
   # PEs - On admission pt w/ borderline BPs and considered not a surgical
   candidate. Progressively developed worsening tachycardia and hypoxia.
   Formal TTE and Cardiology consult --> TPA for lysis on [**5-17**] with
   improvement of HR and SaO2. Repeat TTE yesterday shows continued
   depressed RV function; however, right ventricular abnl is now better
   characterized as limpoma rather than clot. No evidence of bleeding.
   Also s/p IVC filter placement.
   - appreciate cardiology involvement, s/p lysis by TPA
   - cont lovenox to help minimize fluid intake, holding off on coumadin
   pending GI evaluation
   # Edema - Pt w/ increased edema as he has gotten several IVF boluses
   for his Hypotension. Lasix gtt w/ good effect on UOP, although pt still
   getting quite a bit of fluid in.
   - check for obligate Ins, consider changing some meds to PO rather than
   IV
   - cont lasix gtt to keep negative
   # Hypotension - Developed post-lysis w/ TPA. Responsive to IVF.
   Initially thought to be [**2-15**] micro-emboli and expected to improve, but
   now more likely related to underlying infection and fevers. Transiently
   required pressors, but now off.
   - cont to monitor BP closely
   - continue home Florinef
   # Anemia - Likely dilutional considering pt received 4L PRBCs, but in
   setting of lysis and vague h/o GIB. HCT down 32->29. No melena.
   - Guaiac stools
   - recheck HCt
   # Alcohol withdrawal - Significant EtOH history. Should now be out of
   window for withdrawal.
   - daily thiamine / MVI / folate
   - SW consult
   # Recent GIB - Unclear history, ? significant.
   - PPI IV BID
   - GI consulted, no endoscopy now, but will scope prior to discharge
   # Low phos: resolved
   - replete
   - recheck in pm
   - nutrition consult
   # Renal insufficieny - Improved.
   ICU Care

   67-year-old man w/ EtOH abuse, recent GIB, h/o DVTs, p/w multifocal
   PEs, now septic.
   # Sepsis
 Resolving, now normotensive. Pt spiking fevers, tachycardic,
   and hypotensive several days ago but without elevation in WBC. Has
   bottles blood Cx growing CoNS, sputum growing multiple GNRs, and stool
   C.diff positive. Did have infiltrate on CXR concerning for VAP.
   Currently on Zosyn, and Vanc PO, Flagyl. 3 sputum cx all growing GNRs.
   Still spiking fevers, new cultures growing Coag (+) Staph.
   - cont Zosyn (Day 6), for GNR
   - cont Vanc IV (Day 3) for GPCs
   - cont Flagyl (Day 7), PO Vanc (Day 5) for C.diff
   - f/u all culture data, obtain specation of GNR/GPCs
   - draw cultures through a-line and CVL lines
   - gentle diuresis to keep even
   # Unresponsive: likely related to Versed in the setting of EtOh abuse;
   however did get lyisi is at risk for intracranial hemorrhage. Head CT
   neg for bleed and he is moving all 4 extremities, so suspect this is
   sedation related. This morning, he is more responsive, following
   commands, but still not opening eyes. Now extubated with significantly
   improving mental status.
   - hold any mind-altering medications
   # Hypoxic Resp Failure: Extubated with improving hypoxia.
   - monitor secretions
   # VAP: + sputum, fevers and new infiltrate. Sputum growing GNR/GPCs
   - cont Zosyn/Vanc for 8 day course unless grows pseudomonas
   # PEs - On admission pt w/ borderline BPs and considered not a surgical
   candidate. Progressively developed worsening tachycardia and hypoxia.
   Formal TTE and Cardiology consult --> TPA for lysis on [**5-17**] with
   improvement of HR and SaO2. Repeat TTE yesterday shows continued
   depressed RV function; however, right ventricular abnl is now better
   characterized as limpoma rather than clot. No evidence of bleeding.
   Also s/p IVC filter placement.
   - appreciate cardiology involvement, s/p lysis by TPA
   - cont lovenox to help minimize fluid intake, holding off on coumadin
   pending GI evaluation
   # Edema - Pt w/ increased edema as he has gotten several IVF boluses
   for his Hypotension. Lasix gtt w/ good effect on UOP, although pt still
   getting quite a bit of fluid in.
   - check for obligate Ins, consider changing some meds to PO rather than
   IV
   - cont lasix gtt to keep negative
   # Hypotension - Developed post-lysis w/ TPA. Responsive to IVF.
   Initially thought to be [**2-15**] micro-emboli and expected to improve, but
   now more likely related to underlying infection and fevers. Transiently
   required pressors, but now off.
   - cont to monitor BP closely
   - continue home Florinef
   # Anemia - Likely dilutional considering pt received 4L PRBCs, but in
   setting of lysis and vague h/o GIB. HCT down 32->29. No melena.
   - Guaiac stools
   - recheck HCt
   # Alcohol withdrawal - Significant EtOH history. Should now be out of
   window for withdrawal.
   - daily thiamine / MVI / folate
   - SW consult
   # Recent GIB - Unclear history, ? significant.
   - PPI IV BID
   - GI consulted, no endoscopy now, but will scope prior to discharge
   # Low phos: resolved
   - replete
   - recheck in pm
   - nutrition consult
   # Renal insufficieny - Improved.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 67-year-old man with a history of EtOH abuse, recent gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB), and deep vein thrombosis (DVT). He was admitted with hypoxia and has been diagnosed with sepsis, multifocal pulmonary embolisms (PEs), and C. difficile infection.

The patient has been treated with various medications, including Zosyn, vancomycin, and flagyl, and has had multiple cultures taken. His blood cultures are growing Citrobacter freundii complex, Aeromonas hydrophila, and Staph aureus coag+.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 37.6°C (99.7°F)
* Heart rate: 116 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 121/69 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 23 inspirations per minute (ins/min)
* Oxygen saturation: 96%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: CVP 7 mmHg

The patient's physical examination is as follows:

* General: appears comfortable
* HEENT: sclera anicteric
* Neck: LJI in place
* Pulm: lungs clear bilaterally
* CV: regular S1 S2 no murmur or gallop
* Abd: soft +bowel sounds RUQ tender
* Extrem: warm 1+ pitting edema bilaterally, palpable distal pulses
* Neuro: alert and answering appropriately, moving all extremities

The patient's laboratory results are as follows:

* White blood cell count: 13.6
* Hematocrit: 28.4
* Platelet count: 351
* Creatinine: 1.0
* Blood urea nitrogen: 140 mg/dL
* Glucose: 127 mg/dL
* Electrolytes: sodium 140 mg/dL, potassium 3.6 mEq/L, chloride 101 mEq/L, bicarbonate 26.9%
* Lactic acid: 1.1 mmol/L
* Albumin: 1.9 g/dL
* LDH: 333 IU/L
* Calcium: 7.6 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.1 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 2.4 mg/dL

The patient's medical conditions include:

* PAIN CONTROL (acute pain, chronic pain)
* DEEP VENOUS THROMBOSIS (DVT), LOWER EXTREMITY
* FEVER, UNKNOWN ORIGIN (FUO, HYPERTHERMIA, PYREXIA)
* ELECTROLYTE & FLUID DISORDER, OTHER
* RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS)
* ALTERED MENTAL STATUS (NOT DELIRIUM)
* C. DIFFICILE INFECTION (C DIFF, CDIFF COLITIS, CLOSTRIDIUM DIFFICILE)
* PULMONARY EMBOLISM (PE), ACUTE

The patient's plan includes:

* Continue Zosyn for 8 days unless the culture grows pseudomonas
* Continue vancomycin IV for 3 days
* Continue flagyl PO for 7 days
* Obtain specific species of GNR/GPCs
* Draw cultures through a-line and CVL lines
* Gentle diuresis to keep even
* Monitor secretions
* Hold any mind-altering medications
* Continue to monitor BP closely
* Continue to monitor electrolytes and fluids
* Consider changing some medications to PO rather than IV
* Continue lasix gtt to keep negative
* Continue to monitor for signs of infection and sepsis

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Sepsis
* Respiratory failure
* Pneumonia
* C. difficile infection
* Pulmonary embolism
* Deep vein thrombosis
* Electrolyte and fluid disorder
* Renal insufficiency
* Anemia
* Hypotension
* Fever, unknown origin
* Altered mental status
* Pain control

The patient's plan for transfer to the floor includes:

* Continue to monitor vital signs and laboratory results
* Continue to administer medications as ordered
* Continue to monitor for signs of infection and sepsis
* Continue to monitor for signs of respiratory failure
* Continue to monitor for signs of C. difficile infection
* Continue to monitor for signs of pulmonary embolism
* Continue to monitor for signs of deep vein thrombosis
* Continue to monitor for signs of electrolyte and fluid disorder
* Continue to monitor for signs of renal insufficiency
* Continue to monitor for signs of anemia
* Continue to monitor for signs of hypotension

* Continue to monitor for signs of pain control

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health status as follows:

The patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of DVT, GIB, and recent multifocal PE, who has undergone thrombolysis and IVC filter placement. He is currently intubated and sedated, with a tachycardic rhythm. His respiratory status is stable, with SpO2 at 96% on nasal cannula oxygen. He has a fever, with a recent diagnosis of VAP and C. difficile infection. His laboratory results show anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated liver enzymes. He has a history of renal insufficiency and is receiving diuretic therapy.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's recent diagnosis of VAP and C. difficile infection increases his risk of respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's fever and positive cultures for GNR and Staph may indicate sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
3. Bleeding: The patient's history of GIB and recent thrombolysis therapy increases his risk of bleeding complications.
4. Renal failure: The patient's history of renal insufficiency and ongoing diuretic therapy may exacerbate his kidney dysfunction.
5. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's tachycardic rhythm and recent hypotension may indicate cardiovascular instability.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's recent diagnosis of VAP and C. difficile infection may lead to neurological complications such as meningitis or encephalitis.
7. Infection control: The patient's positive cultures for GNR and Staph may indicate a lack of effective infection control measures, which can lead to further complications.

In conclusion, the patient's health status is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and recent gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB). He has been diagnosed with bilateral pulmonary embolism (PE) and has undergone thrombolysis and placement of an inferior vena cava (IVC) filter.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation. He has a fever and is positive for Citrobacter and Staph in his sputum.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has tachycardia and elevated jugular venous distension (JVD).
* Renal: The patient has renal insufficiency, but his creatinine level has improved.
* Neurological: The patient is awake and responding to stimuli, but has decreased tremor.
* Hematological: The patient has a platelet count of 351 K/uL and an international normalized ratio (INR) of 1.1.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count (WBC): 13.6
* Hematocrit (Hct): 28.4
* Platelet count: 351 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.0 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 36 mg/dL
* Serum albumin: 1.9 g/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.1 mmol/L
* Calcium: 7.6 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.1 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 2.4 mg/dL

The patient's medications include:

* Enoxaparin (Lovenox) for DVT prophylaxis
* Pantoprazole (Protonix) for stress ulcer prophylaxis
* Furosemide (Lasix) for volume overload
* Piperacillin/Tazobactam (Zosyn) for antibiotic coverage
* Vancomycin for antibiotic coverage
* Chlorhexidine for skin care
* Colace for bowel care
* Thiamine for nutritional support
* Protonix Q12 for gastric acid suppression
* Fludrocortisone qday for volume overload
* Folic acid for nutritional support
* MVI for nutritional support

The patient's plan includes:

* Continuing antibiotic coverage for 8 days for Gram-negative coverage
* Continuing vancomycin for 2 weeks and 1 week post-antibiotics
* Focusing on nutritional intake and improving cough and secretion clearance
* Evaluating the patient's risk for rebleeding after his acute issues have resolved
* Placing a central line and attempting to place 2 peripheral lines
* Continuing stress ulcer prophylaxis with pantoprazole
* Continuing DVT prophylaxis with enoxaparin

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Pneumonia due to the patient's positive sputum culture
* Sepsis due to the patient's positive blood culture
* Renal failure due to the patient's renal insufficiency
* Respiratory failure due to the patient's tachypnea and decreased lung function
* Bleeding due to the patient's anticoagulation therapy
* Infection due to the patient's central line and peripheral lines
* Volume overload due to the patient's fluid overload and electrolyte imbalance.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with multiple comorbidities and ongoing medical issues. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.2°C, heart rate of 119 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 124/74 mmHg. The patient is receiving multiple medications, including antibiotics, anticoagulants, and diuretics.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of acute kidney injury, electrolyte imbalance, and liver dysfunction. The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, and the differential count shows a predominance of neutrophils.

The patient's clinical assessment reveals signs of acute pain, deep venous thrombosis, fever of unknown origin, respiratory failure, altered mental status, and Clostridium difficile infection. The patient also has a pulmonary embolism and is at risk for further complications.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's fever and elevated white blood cell count suggest the possibility of sepsis, which could lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure could worsen, leading to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) or cardiac arrest.
3. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's electrolyte imbalance could lead to cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, or seizures.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute kidney injury could worsen, leading to end-stage renal disease or the need for dialysis.
5. Clostridium difficile infection: The patient's Clostridium difficile infection could lead to further complications, such as colonic perforation or sepsis.
6. Pulmonary embolism: The patient's pulmonary embolism could worsen, leading to respiratory failure, cardiac arrest, or death.
7. Deep venous thrombosis: The patient's deep venous thrombosis could lead to pulmonary embolism, post-thrombotic syndrome, or chronic pain.
8. Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status could worsen, leading to delirium, coma, or death.
9. Sternal wound infection: The patient's sternal wound infection could lead to further complications, such as sepsis, organ failure, or death.

These potential medical complications highlight the need for close monitoring and aggressive management of the patient's condition to prevent further deterioration and improve outcomes.

   Blood ([**5-18**], [**5-19**]):  Negative
   Blood ([**5-21**], [**5-22**], [**5-25**]):  NGTD

   Assessment and Plan:  67-year-old man w/ EtOH abuse, recent GIB, h/o
   DVTs, p/w multifocal PEs, now septic.
   # Pulmonary embolism:  On admission pt w/ borderline BPs and considered
   not a surgical candidate. Progressively developed worsening tachycardia
   and hypoxia. Formal TTE and Cardiology consult --> TPA for lysis on [**5-17**]
   with improvement of HR and SaO2. Repeat TTE [**5-18**]  shows continued
   depressed RV function; however, right ventricular abnl is now better
   characterized as limpoma rather than clot. No evidence of bleeding.
   Also s/p IVC filter placement. Blood pressure recently stable.
   - Appreciate cardiology involvement, s/p lysis by TPA
   - Continue lovenox to help minimize fluid intake, holding off on
   coumadin pending GI evaluation
   # Ventilator associated pneumonia:  Clinically improved without
   significant fever or sputum in the last day. Sputum growing
   Citrobacter, Aeromonas, and vancomycin
   - Continue Zosyn (D1: [**5-19**])
   - Continue vancomycin (D1: [**5-21**])
   - Plan for 8 days of antibiotics; awaiting final sensitivities before
   pealing off meds
   # Edema: Total body overloaded in the setting of IVF resuscitation for
   his hypotension.
   - Continue IV lasix boluses goal -1 to 2L negative
   # Anemia:  Hct trending down, without any evidence of gross bleeding
   here. Of note, he does have a history of GIB and is s/p thrombolysis
   and on LMWH. Macrocytosis likely secondary to liver disease, but
   consider also b12 deficiency.
   - Follow Hct [**Hospital1 7**]
   - Continue PPI [**Hospital1 **]; change to oral
   - Maintain active T+S, transfuse hct>25
   - Place two PIV; once in, can d/c CVL once PIV in
   - GI to perform EGD and colonoscopy on floor
   - Check iron panel, folate, b12
   # C. diff colitis:  Clinically improved, has been treated with both PO
   vancomycin and metronidazole.
   - Complete 10d course of PO vancomycin following completion of Zosyn
   for HAP
   - Discontinue PO metronidazole
   # Alcohol withdrawal: Significant EtOH history. Should now be out of
   window for withdrawal and was loaded up front.
   - Daily thiamine / MVI / folate
   - SW consult
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Fibersource HN (Full) - [**2162-5-24**] 10:35 PM 70 mL/hour

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 67-year-old man with a history of ethanol abuse, recent gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB), and deep vein thromboses (DVTs). He was admitted with bilateral pulmonary embolisms (PEs) and sepsis.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.4°C (99.4°F), heart rate of 110 bpm, and blood pressure of 99/64 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 96% on a nasal cannula.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 13.6 K/μL, hemoglobin of 8.2 g/dL, and platelet count of 124 K/μL. His liver function tests are elevated, with an alanine aminotransferase (ALT) of 11-4 IU/L and an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) of 91 IU/L. His kidney function is also compromised, with a creatinine of 1.0 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) of 16 mg/dL.

The patient has been treated with various medications, including antibiotics for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), anticoagulants for DVT prophylaxis, and stress ulcer prophylaxis with an oral proton pump inhibitor (PPI). He has also received thrombolytic therapy for pulmonary embolism lysis.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis may worsen, leading to organ dysfunction and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. Pulmonary embolism: The patient's bilateral PEs may progress, leading to further respiratory compromise and potentially life-threatening complications.
3. Ventilator-associated pneumonia: The patient's VAP may worsen, leading to further respiratory compromise and potentially life-threatening complications.
4. C. difficile colitis: The patient's C. difficile colitis may worsen, leading to further gastrointestinal complications and potentially life-threatening complications.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen, leading to further cardiovascular compromise and potentially life-threatening complications.
6. Liver dysfunction: The patient's liver dysfunction may worsen, leading to further complications and potentially life-threatening complications.
7. Kidney dysfunction: The patient's kidney dysfunction may worsen, leading to further complications and potentially life-threatening complications.
8. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may worsen, leading to further bleeding complications and potentially life-threatening complications.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust his treatment plan accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual admitted to the ICU with a temperature spike to 101.3°C, tachycardia, and altered mental status. The patient is receiving multiple medications, including antibiotics, pain management, and electrolyte supplements.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's temperature spike and tachycardia may indicate a possible sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, with a need for oxygen therapy and an abnormal ABG reading. This may indicate a risk of respiratory failure.
3. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient is at risk for DVT due to immobility and may require prophylactic measures.
4. Pneumonia: The patient's fever and abnormal lung function may indicate a possible pneumonia, which can worsen respiratory status.
5. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's electrolyte levels are abnormal, which may lead to cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and other complications.
6. C. difficile infection: The patient has a history of C. difficile infection, which can lead to diarrhea, abdominal pain, and electrolyte imbalances.
7. Pulmonary embolism (PE): The patient's tachycardia and abnormal lung function may indicate a possible PE, which can lead to respiratory failure and cardiac arrest.

The patient's altered mental status and agitation may be related to pain, electrolyte imbalance, or medication side effects. The patient's code status is full code, indicating that all possible measures should be taken to resuscitate the patient in the event of cardiac arrest.

Further monitoring and management of the patient's condition are necessary to prevent and treat these potential complications.

   MRSA screen ([**5-16**]):  Negative

   Blood ([**5-18**], [**5-19**]):  Negative
   Blood ([**5-21**], [**5-22**], [**5-25**]):  NGTD

   Assessment and Plan:  67-year-old man w/ EtOH abuse, recent GIB, h/o
   DVTs, p/w multifocal PEs, now septic.
   # Pulmonary embolism:  On admission pt w/ borderline BPs and considered
   not a surgical candidate. Progressively developed worsening tachycardia
   and hypoxia. Formal TTE and Cardiology consult --> TPA for lysis on [**5-17**]
   with improvement of HR and SaO2. Repeat TTE [**5-18**]  shows continued
   depressed RV function; however, right ventricular abnl is now better
   characterized as limpoma rather than clot. No evidence of bleeding.
   Also s/p IVC filter placement. Blood pressure recently stable.
   - Appreciate cardiology involvement, s/p lysis by TPA
   - Continue lovenox to help minimize fluid intake, holding off on
   coumadin pending GI evaluation
   # Ventilator associated pneumonia:  Clinically improved without
   significant fever or sputum in the last day. Sputum growing
   Citrobacter, Aeromonas, and vancomycin
   - Continue Zosyn (D1: [**5-19**])
   - Continue vancomycin (D1: [**5-21**])
   - Plan for 8 days of antibiotics; awaiting final sensitivities before
   pealing off meds
   # Edema: Total body overloaded in the setting of IVF resuscitation for
   his hypotension.
   - Continue IV lasix boluses goal -1 to 2L negative
   # Anemia:  Hct trending down, without any evidence of gross bleeding
   here. Of note, he does have a history of GIB and is s/p thrombolysis
   and on LMWH. Macrocytosis likely secondary to liver disease, but
   consider also b12 deficiency.
   - Follow Hct [**Hospital1 7**]
   - Continue PPI [**Hospital1 **]; change to oral
   - Maintain active T+S, transfuse hct>25
   - Place two PIV; once in, can d/c CVL once PIV in
   - GI to perform EGD and colonoscopy on floor
   - Check iron panel, folate, b12
   # C. diff colitis:  Clinically improved, has been treated with both PO
   vancomycin and metronidazole.
   - Complete 10d course of PO vancomycin following completion of Zosyn
   for HAP
   - Discontinue PO metronidazole
   # Alcohol withdrawal: Significant EtOH history. Should now be out of
   window for withdrawal and was loaded up front.
   - Daily thiamine / MVI / folate
   - SW consult
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:

   Assessment and Plan:  67-year-old man w/ EtOH abuse, recent GIB, h/o
   DVTs, p/w multifocal PEs, now septic.
   # Fevers
   Pt currently being treated for VAP, with sputum cultures growing
   Citrobacter, aeromonas, and S. aureus (sensitivites on the latter two
   organisms are pending). CXR not worsening and O2 requirement stable
   arguing against progression of pna. Consider also line infection, UTI,
   drug fever, clot/PE. Of note, PO vancomycin discontinued yesterday for
   C diff though he continues on PO flagyl. Back pain c/w prior at home
   but also consider possibility of spinal osteo.
   - Follow up pending urine and blood cultures, repeat cultures if
   febrile
   - DC foley and central line
   - Call lab for sensitivities on aeromonas and staph
   - Consider L spine MRI though back pain is chronic
   # Tachycardia
   Likely multifactorial, pt with recent large PE and infection
   - Follow on telemetry, treating infection and PE
   # Pulmonary embolism:  On admission pt w/ borderline BPs and considered
   not a surgical candidate. Progressively developed worsening tachycardia
   and hypoxia. Formal TTE and Cardiology consult --> TPA for lysis on [**5-17**]
   with improvement of HR and SaO2. Repeat TTE [**5-18**]  shows continued
   depressed RV function; however, right ventricular abnl is now better
   characterized as limpoma rather than clot. No evidence of bleeding.
   Also s/p IVC filter placement. Blood pressure recently stable.
   - Appreciate cardiology involvement, s/p lysis by TPA
   - Continue lovenox to help minimize fluid intake, holding off on
   coumadin pending GI evaluation
   # Ventilator associated pneumonia:  Clinically improved. Sputum growing
   Citrobacter, Aeromonas, staph aureus.
   - Continue Zosyn (D1: [**5-19**])
   - Continue vancomycin (D1: [**5-21**])
   - Plan for 8 days of antibiotics; awaiting final sensitivities before
   pealing off meds
   # Edema: Total body overloaded in the setting of IVF resuscitation for
   his hypotension.
   - Will hold off on further diuresis today
   # Anemia:  Hct trending down, without any evidence of gross bleeding
   here. Of note, he does have a history of GIB and is s/p thrombolysis
   and on LMWH. Macrocytosis likely secondary to liver disease, but
   consider also b12 deficiency.
   - Follow daily hct
   - Continue PPI [**Hospital1 7**]
   - Maintain active T+S, transfuse hct>25
   - Place two PIV; once in, can d/c CVL
   - GI to perform EGD and colonoscopy on floor
   - Repeat iron studies as outpatient
   # C. diff colitis:  Clinically improved, has been treated with both PO
   vancomycin.
   - Complete 14d course of PO flagyl  following completion of VAP
   antibiotics
   # Alcohol withdrawal: Significant EtOH history. Should now be out of
   window for withdrawal and was loaded up front.
   - Daily thiamine / MVI / folate
   - SW consult ([**5-26**])

Summary:

The patient is a 67-year-old man with a history of ethanol abuse, recent gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB), and deep vein thrombosis (DVT). He was admitted with multifocal pulmonary embolisms (PEs) and sepsis. He has been treated for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) with sputum cultures growing Citrobacter, Aeromonas, and Staphylococcus aureus. He has also been treated for C. difficile colitis with PO vancomycin and flagyl. He has been experiencing fever, tachycardia, and hypoxia, and has been on IV fluids and antibiotics.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Line infection: The patient has multiple lines in place, including a central line, which may be infected.
2. Urinary tract infection (UTI): The patient has a Foley catheter in place, which may be a source of infection.
3. Drug fever: The patient is receiving multiple antibiotics, which may cause a fever.
4. Clot/PE: The patient has a history of DVT and PE, and may be at risk for further clotting or PE.
5. Spinal osteoarthritis: The patient has back pain, which may be related to spinal osteoarthritis.
6. Liver disease: The patient has macrocytosis, which may be related to liver disease.
7. B12 deficiency: The patient may be at risk for B12 deficiency due to his liver disease and malnutrition.
8. C. difficile colitis: The patient has been treated for C. difficile colitis, but may still be at risk for recurrence.
9. VAP: The patient has VAP, which may lead to further respiratory complications.
10. Anemia: The patient has anemia, which may be related to his GIB, liver disease, or malnutrition.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results to assess for any changes in his condition.
2. Consider performing a CT scan or MRI to rule out any further clotting or PE.
3. Continue to treat the patient's VAP with antibiotics and consider performing a bronchoscopy to obtain a better specimen.
4. Consider performing a colonoscopy to evaluate the patient's colonic mucosa and rule out any further inflammation.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's blood sugar levels and adjust his insulin dose as needed.
6. Consider performing a liver function test to evaluate the patient's liver function and rule out any further liver damage.
7. Consider performing a B12 level test to assess for any deficiencies.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's nutritional status and adjust his diet as needed.
9. Consider performing a stress test to evaluate the patient's cardiac function and rule out any further cardiac complications.
